articles.headline: China Reportedly Plans Strict Goals to Save Energy
articles.snippet: The five-year goal reflects concerns about the effects of high fuel costs on national security, inflation, trade and pollution.
articles.abstract: The five-year goal reflects concerns about the effects of high fuel costs on national security, inflation, trade and pollution.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  With oil prices at their highest level in more than two years because of unrest in North Africa and the Middle East, the Chinese government plans to announce strict five-year goals for energy conservation in the next two weeks, China energy specialists said Friday.

articles.headline: Power of Apparel: A Look That Conveys a Message
articles.snippet: Top-flight executives can have stylists select their look. But some opt for simplicity as the ultimate power suit.
articles.abstract: Top-flight executives can have stylists select their look. But some opt for simplicity as the ultimate power suit.
articles.lead_paragraph: To tour an assembly plant in Canada, Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of Chrysler, wore a black sweater and a checked oxford shirt.

articles.headline: Adding It Up: Amazon Ship vs. Costco Shop
articles.snippet: Costco is popular for its low prices, but shopping there can take time. Does Amazon’s Subscribe & Save service provide a better alternative?
articles.abstract: Costco is popular for its low prices, but shopping there can take time. Does Amazon’s Subscribe & Save service provide a better alternative?
articles.lead_paragraph: For millions of Costco customers, this is an eagerly awaited time of year. Right about now is when their big annual rebate checks arrive from American Express.

articles.headline: Mortgage Modification Overhaul Sought by States
articles.snippet: A plan could give the government sweeping authority over how mortgage servicers deal with homeowners.
articles.abstract: A plan could give the government sweeping authority over how mortgage servicers deal with homeowners.
articles.lead_paragraph: State attorneys general have presented the nation’s five biggest banks with a list of demands that could drastically alter the foreclosure process and give the government sweeping authority over how mortgage servicers deal with millions of Americans in danger of losing their homes.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and David Streitfeld

articles.headline: Radical Cleric Still Speaks on YouTube
articles.snippet: The videos of Anwar al-Awlaki, the man some have called the Osama bin Laden of the Internet, still appear despite an effort by YouTube to remove them.
articles.abstract: The videos of Anwar al-Awlaki, the man some have called the Osama bin Laden of the Internet, still appear despite an effort by YouTube to remove them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  From the shootings at Fort Hood, Tex., to the stabbing of a British member of Parliament, investigators have identified Anwar al-Awlaki’s stirring online calls to jihad as an important instigator of terrorism.

articles.headline: In Libya, Both Sides Gird for Long War as Civilian Toll Mounts
articles.snippet: Gunfire could be heard in Tripoli on Sunday as both sides of the conflict girded for a confrontation in the coming days at the port of Surt, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s birthplace, which blocks the rebels’ progress toward the capital.
articles.abstract: Gunfire could be heard in Tripoli on Sunday as both sides of the conflict girded for a confrontation in the coming days at the port of Surt, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s birthplace, which blocks the rebels’ progress toward the capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya  Each side of the conflict in Libya pushed forward on Saturday as militia forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi launched a second day of attacks on the rebel-held city of Zawiyah, just 30 miles west of the capital, and a ragtag rebel army moving from the east won its first ground battle to take the oil port of Ras Lanuf, about midway down the Mediterranean coast.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: Hey, S.E.C., That Escape Hatch Is Still Open
articles.snippet: Although the S.E.C. calls itself “the investor’s advocate,” it’s still not enforcing a rule governing credit ratings agencies.
articles.abstract: Although the S.E.C. calls itself “the investor’s advocate,” it’s still not enforcing a rule governing credit ratings agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S hard to say what’s more exasperating: the woeful performance of the credit ratings agencies during the recent mortgage securities boom or the failure to hold them accountable in the bust that followed.

articles.headline: MERS? It May Have Swallowed Your Loan
articles.snippet: An obscure company claims to hold title to roughly half of the home mortgages in the nation — 60 million loans.
articles.abstract: An obscure company claims to hold title to roughly half of the home mortgages in the nation — 60 million loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR more than a decade, the American real estate market resembled an overstuffed novel, which is to say, it was an engrossing piece of fiction.
articles.byline: By Michael Powell and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: Soup Without Fins? Some Californians Simmer
articles.snippet: In a move that has infuriated many in San Francisco’s Chinatown, a state bill would ban the sale and possession of shark fins, including the serving of shark’s fin soup.
articles.abstract: In a move that has infuriated many in San Francisco’s Chinatown, a state bill would ban the sale and possession of shark fins, including the serving of shark’s fin soup.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  As the proprietor of Chung Chou City, a packed-to-the-gills dried seafood emporium in Chinatown here, Anna Li presides over barrels full of coveted ingredients like dried shrimp eggs and scallops and fried fish stomachs.

articles.headline: Off the Catwalk, the Battle for Hermès
articles.snippet: The LVMH conglomerate is angling to take over Hermès. But the Hermès family has rallied against the idea.
articles.abstract: The LVMH conglomerate is angling to take over Hermès. But the Hermès family has rallied against the idea.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS

articles.headline: To Quiet Critics, Romney Puts 2012 Focus on Jobs
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney made the case in a speech that the halting economic recovery provides the most compelling rationale that he should take on President Obama.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney made the case in a speech that the halting economic recovery provides the most compelling rationale that he should take on President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARTLETT, N.H.  As Mitt Romney travels the country lining up contributors and influential Republicans for a second presidential bid, he is presenting himself as a ready-to-lead executive, gambling that a fluency in economic matters distinguishes him from other candidates and can help overcome concerns about authenticity that dogged his first race.

articles.headline: Egyptian Army’s Business Side Blurs Lines of U.S. Military Aid
articles.snippet: The $1.3 billion a year in military aid that Washington gives Cairo has served to shore up a bureaucracy prone to corruption.
articles.abstract: The $1.3 billion a year in military aid that Washington gives Cairo has served to shore up a bureaucracy prone to corruption.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the late 1990s, the Pentagon announced that it would contribute tens of millions of dollars to a 650-bed International Medical Center that the Egyptian military was building in the desert outside Cairo. The money, for medical equipment, training and logistical support, would help improve health care for Egyptian soldiers.
articles.byline: By Aram Roston and David Rohde

articles.headline: So Far Rivals Can’t Beat iPad’s Price
articles.snippet: Industry experts do not expect the many iPad clones this year to be competitive on price. Apple has many advantages, like component cost and distribution.
articles.abstract: Industry experts do not expect the many iPad clones this year to be competitive on price. Apple has many advantages, like component cost and distribution.
articles.lead_paragraph: The iPad 2, unveiled on Wednesday, offers several sleek improvements over its predecessor. But its most attractive feature is perhaps the same one its predecessor had: the price tag.

articles.headline: Free of Qaddafi, a City Tries to Build a New Order
articles.snippet: Bayda, one of the first places to embrace the anti-Qaddafi revolution, has now also embraced the work of what might follow.
articles.abstract: Bayda, one of the first places to embrace the anti-Qaddafi revolution, has now also embraced the work of what might follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAYDA, Libya — The signs in Bayda still read the Great Socialist People’s Libyan Arab State of the Masses. It was never much of a state, nor did the people have much say. Now two weeks after its liberation, residents of this highland town have the task of making it so, a challenge that may prove pivotal to the course of Libya’s revolt.

articles.headline: The Fading Power of Beck’s Alarms
articles.snippet: Glenn Beck’s recipe of socialist conspiracy and chronic desperation is wearing thin, according to his ratings.
articles.abstract: Glenn Beck’s recipe of socialist conspiracy and chronic desperation is wearing thin, according to his ratings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Almost every time I flipped on television last week, there was a deeply angry guy on a running tirade about the conspiracies afoot, the enemies around all corners, and how he alone seemed to understand what was under way.

articles.headline: Sheen Is Surrounded by a Coterie of Enablers
articles.snippet: In Hollywood, stars like Charlie Sheen often live insulated from the consequences of their bad behavior.
articles.abstract: In Hollywood, stars like Charlie Sheen often live insulated from the consequences of their bad behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Since getting sober more than two decades ago, Tom Arnold, the actor and comedian, has been a quiet force in Hollywood’s recovery community, helping stage a number of interventions for drug-addicted executives and alcoholic stars.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes, Bill Carter and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: ABC Family Spins Gold in Dramas
articles.snippet: Michael Riley has just taken over the ABC Family channel, one of television’s hottest brands, and is about to get three new original dramas for its schedule.
articles.abstract: Michael Riley has just taken over the ABC Family channel, one of television’s hottest brands, and is about to get three new original dramas for its schedule.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif.  If Michael G. Riley, the new president of ABC Family, comes across as a bit nervous these days, cut him some slack. Only seven months ago he was working in radio. Now he’s about to lead a major expansion of one of television’s hottest brands.

articles.headline: Drug Firms Face Billions in Losses in ’11 as Patents End
articles.snippet: The drug industry will lose control over more than 10 medicines with sales of nearly $50 billion this year, a reversal that highlights the problems drug companies now face.
articles.abstract: The drug industry will lose control over more than 10 medicines with sales of nearly $50 billion this year, a reversal that highlights the problems drug companies now face.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the end of November, Pfizer stands to lose a $10-billion-a-year revenue stream when the patent on its blockbuster cholesterol drug Lipitor expires and cheaper generics begin to cut into the company’s huge sales.

articles.headline: A Libyan Leader at War With Rebels, and Reality
articles.snippet: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s personal mythology has kept him in power over a deeply divided tribal society.
articles.abstract: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s personal mythology has kept him in power over a deeply divided tribal society.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Residents here were awakened before dawn on Sunday by the sound of artillery and gunfire in the streets. When they tuned into state television broadcasts, they heard stunning news: the Libyan military had routed the rebels seeking to oust Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. The gunfire, they were told, was in celebration.

articles.headline: White House Seeks to Allay Muslims’ Fears on Terror Hearings
articles.snippet: As hearings approach on the threat of homegrown Islamic terrorism, the White House is trying to reassure Muslims.
articles.abstract: As hearings approach on the threat of homegrown Islamic terrorism, the White House is trying to reassure Muslims.
articles.lead_paragraph: STERLING, Va. — As a Republican congressman prepares to open hearings on the threat of homegrown Islamic terrorism, President Obama’s deputy national security adviser visited a mosque here on Sunday to reassure Muslims that “we will not stigmatize or demonize entire communities because of the actions of a few.”

articles.headline: Mexican Church Takes a Closer Look at Donors
articles.snippet: The Roman Catholic Church in Mexico has been trying to confront its historic ties to drug traffickers and their gifts.
articles.abstract: The Roman Catholic Church in Mexico has been trying to confront its historic ties to drug traffickers and their gifts.
articles.lead_paragraph: PACHUCA, Mexico  The large orange chapel here, with its towering cross, would be just another Roman Catholic church if not for a bronze plaque announcing that it was “donated by Heriberto Lazcano Lazcano”  better known as “the executioner,” commander of the ruthless crime syndicate called the Zetas.

articles.headline: Russia Cashes In on Anxiety Over Supply of Middle East Oil
articles.snippet: Perceptions of stability in Russia and instability in OPEC have lifted the ruble and Russian Micex index.
articles.abstract: Perceptions of stability in Russia and instability in OPEC have lifted the ruble and Russian Micex index.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  Whatever the eventual outcome of the Arab world’s social upheaval, there is a clear economic winner so far: Vladimir V. Putin.
